player_decision.reason: We have a decent T♠J♣ offsuit in a heads-up pot with 5/10 blinds. Calling 5 to see a flop gives us pot odds to realize equity with two overcards and potential straight/backdoor possibilities, while keeping the pot manageable instead of risking a bigger raise or folding too often.

Heads-up vs a limp: a small raise to 20 (10 more) applies pressure and can take the pot now. 9s4s has some play postflop when called, but checking invites opponent to see cheap flop; prefer to be aggressive to try to win the pot outright.

You have TsJc in the blinds facing a 20 bet with 75 chips left. Calling to see a flop gives you decent equity with backdoor straight possibilities and two overcards, while keeping the pot small and preserving stack for future edges. Folding is too tight here and a raise is likely too aggressive with a marginal hand.

As preflop aggressor, my hand has very little flop equity (no pair, only weak backdoor draws). Make a small continuation bet (~half pot) to apply pressure and try to take down the pot without commitment. Keeps pot manageable if called and preserves fold equity against a wide calling range.

On the flop (3h 5h 6c) with Ts Jc you have only a backdoor runner-runner straight at best and no heart draw. Villain’s flop bet into a 60-pot with a likely made hand OR draw puts you in a tough spot with poor equity. Folding preserves chips for better spots.
